Name: Beattie, Mr. Thomson
Death: Climed in but died of hypothermia

Name: Daly, Mr. Peter Dennis
Remarks: climbed in boat A from the water

Name: Williams, Mr. Richard Norris II
lifeboat: Transfer from A to 14 to D
Remarks: doctor nearly amputated his feet due to severe frostbites but he opted to walk every two hours instead so his tennis career would not be cut short

Name: Abbott, Mrs. Rhoda Mary 'Rosa'
lifeboat: Transfer from A to 14 to D
Remarks: only female passenger who went down with the ship and survived, her husband was a famous boxer, transferred to the titanic due to recent coal strike

Name: Honkanen, Miss. Eliina
lifeboat: Transfer from A to 14 to D
Remarks: rescued in a lifeboat last to leave and she endured many privations

Name: Lindell, Mr. Edvard Bengtsson
Death: a legend tells he couldn't help his wife into the boat, while both were already experiencing hypothermia and died, while Elin was holding onto the lifeboat.

Name: Jansson, Mr. Carl Olof
Profession: jumped into the water to boat A, which then nearly sank and then was transferred to boat 14
Age of Death: He remained onboard, staying with August Wennerström until the ship's final throes before jumping and swimming to waterlogged collapsible A. He later admitted pushing others away from the frail craft in "a tough fight in the water" to prevent it going down due to excess weight.

Name: Abelseth, Mr. Olaus Jørgensen
Remarks: family friend of Karen Abelseth, swam for 20 minutes before reaching the lifeboat, once discovered by the Carpathia he had to sleep in the same wet clothes he swam in on deck, experienced two men freezing to death on lifeboat

Name: Keefe, Mr. Arthur
Death: Climed in but died of hypothermia

Name: Judd, Mr. Charles Edward
lifeboat: Transfer from A to 14 to D
Profession: mentioned the boat was full of water up to his waste which clearly indicates Boat A! He must have been transferred to Boat 14 later on. could have been transferred to Boat D again as well.
Remarks: A to 14 and maybe to D
Age of Death: boat was full of water up to his waist

Name: Willard, Miss. Constance
lifeboat: Transfer from Boat A to D
Age of Death: her account fits A the best: "12 people in it" and only one 1st class passenger. no boat fits it precisely but Boat A has the fewest passenger to first class ratio. still fairly applicable in boat D, which she must have been transfered to.

Name: Unidentified Body
Death: Climed in but died of hypothermia
